name: Model Toolkit & Flow Data Review Tool
description: Originated and led development of an enterprise platform to unify modeling workflows, tools, and data processes in a single AI-enabled environment; defined vision/roadmap/requirements through workshops and user research; worked with external developers on MVP architecture/specs, ingestion concepts, UI/UX mockups, workflow diagrams, and sprint/backlog/QA; integrated capabilities such as flow data QA/QC, ingestion/normalization, event detection, rainfall processing, and calibration dashboards
title: Professional Engineer

name: Wade Trim GO! SharePoint/M365 Digital Delivery Platform Support
description: Supported expansion and client adoption of a SharePoint/M365-based digital delivery platform; advised on content organization, client use patterns, and feature alignment; coordinated with internal teams to integrate project data, dashboards, map updates, and workflows into client sites; supported onboarding and analytics reviews
title: Professional Engineer

name: Autocalibrator (WACK) & SWMM Calibration Automation Toolkit
description: Led development, testing, and deployment of an autocalibration toolkit for SWMM-based models to automate calibration workflows; coordinated with internal SMEs and external partners to evaluate algorithms and cloud-based optimization methods; iterated on parameter normalization, uncertainty handling, multi-event scoring, calibration metrics, and visualization; supported applications for multiple utilities and delivered presentations, documentation, and trainings
title: Professional Engineer
project_role: Technical Advisor/ strategic Lead, Product Owner

name: Resiliency Analysis
description: Level of Service and Resiliency analysis for municipal water systems.
title: Professional Engineer

name: Comprehensive Plan
description: Work with Authority to determine site locations for 10 flow meters and 3 raingages to be used in a SWMM model of the Authority's main interceptors and several key pump stations and syphons. Worked on but did not complete project due to change in job.
title: Senior Project Engineer

name: Hydraulic Model Modernization
description: Embedded on-site at the Cleveland Water Department, I documented existing water distribution modeling practices and procedures. This involved conducting a thorough review of available documentation and interviewing staff to assess knowledge gaps and prepare for future staffing transitions. A report outlining the steps to be taken during a staffing transition and recommendations for modernizing Standard Operating Procedures was subsequently compiled including improvements to GIS practices, upgrades from InfoWater to InfoWater Pro and use of SCADA.
title: Professional Engineer
project_role: Technical Advisor, Modeling Engineer, Task Lead

name: Laurel Run PMF Study
description: Development of an HEC-HMS model to determine Probable Maximum Flood elevation for the Laurel Run Reservoir located in St. Mary's, PA.
title: Senior Project Engineer

name: MSDGC Model Calibration and Model Reviews
description: Worked on SWMM model calibration for the Metropolitan Sewer District of Cincinnati, calibrating several separate sanitary flow meter locations. Also revised and redistributed tributary acreage throughout the model area by developing a custom python script to allocate area along interceptor lines for RDII. Completed model reviews for other consultant model submissions and drafted a final calibration report for the Wade Trim portions of the model calibration effort.
title: Senior Project Engineer

name: PWSA Wet Weather Program Manager
description: Lead engineer for a $17M contract managing a 100-meter flow monitor plan and SWMM model expansion. Task lead overseeing extensive field data collection and integration into SWMM model updates; developed GIS tools supporting flow/asset data collection, InfoAsset Manager integration, and project dashboards; managed a ~130-meter flow monitoring plan including data review, subcontractor coordination, QA/QC, and deliverables; supported LiDAR scanning of diversion structures to capture weir/pipe geometry and provide client-facing access to scan data Key team member on $17 million Wet Weather Program Manager contract including contribution to the winning proposal development. The multi-year programs consists of data management and analysis, data collection, a 100 meter flow monitor plan and SWMM model expansion and calibration. Lead engineer in developing and managing the flow monitoring plan including overseeing multiple subconsultants, QAQC review work and management of quality deliverables.
title: Professional Engineer

name: Python Out File Reader Script
description: Developed a python tool to interface with model .out files and pull requested .tsf files. Later improved this code and had it integrated into the "Autocalibration" tool being developed on behalf of Wade Trim.
title: Professional Engineer

name: Saddle Creek Groundwater Monitoring Dashboard
description: Built a Power BI dashboard to ingest groundwater well readings from IoT sensors.
title: Professional Engineer

name: Zoning Violation Program
description: Developed Survey123 Form with data validation and dependencies along with a dashboard and desktop web map for office management. Process allowed Zoning Officer and staff to create violation reports which were stored in an ArcGIS Online feature service. This was consumed by dashboards and web maps to give insight to office staff and allow updates to violations. Individual violation letters were automatically generated along with summary reports for board meetings.
title: Senior Project Engineer

name: GGSA GIS System Map and Survey
description: Georeferencing old paper maps into a GIS system map and configuration of GIS databases for use in ArcGIS Online. Led the acquisition of new equipment to utilize ArcGIS Online and the Collector app for high accuracy GNSS survey. Developed a dashboard to track survey crews' progress in real time.
title: Senior Project Engineer

name: Water System Hydraulic Model
description: The development of the Hampton-Shaler Water Authority's first modern water distribution model in InfoWater Pro was accomplished using available data sources, including GIS data, record drawings, staff knowledge, and fieldwork. The model comprised 12 tanks, 4 booster stations, a water treatment plant, and numerous interconnections. To enhance accuracy, a hydrant testing program for pipe roughness calibration was planned. Collaborating closely with operators and other staff, data gaps were identified and resolved, and model controls were developed. Subsequently, the model was employed for preliminary planning of new distribution mains and booster stations, as well as for evaluating valve settings and tank performance.
title: Senior Project Engineer

name: Moon Water Model
description: I completed the upgrade of an existing WaterCAD hydraulic model to an InfoWater Pro water distribution model. This project included integrating various system updates, such as the incorporation of the latest infrastructure data. The system encompassed three tank sites, a treatment plant, and various interconnections. Calibration of the model was achieved through hydrant flow and pressure testing throughout the system. Additionally, I implemented data exchange tools to facilitate bi-directional information exchange between the model and GIS data.
title: Senior Project Engineer

name: Salt Run Dam PMF Study
description: Development of an HEC-HMS model to determine Probable Maximum Flood elevation for the Salt Run Reservoir located in Emporium, PA.
title: Senior Project Engineer

name: Smith Township GIS Mapping Program
description: Assisted Smith Township in the selection and purchase of a Trimble R2 GNSS receiver and tablet. Setup ArcGIS Online and feature services to collect and store stormwater, signage, and utility pole locations and information that were owned by the Township. Conducted training and assisted in initial collection.
title: Senior Project Engineer

name: South Strabane Gas Well Mapping
description: Utilized publically available permits for gas wells in and around the township to map all gas well heads and laterals in and around the township. This information was used to communicate to the public and discuss changes to ordinances. An ESRI story map was developed to best communicate the findings in an organized manner.
title: Senior Project Engineer

name: Interceptor System Hydraulic Modeling
description: Completed H&H modeling of the Chartiers and Brush Run Interceptor and accompanying pump stations. Flow data from 20 meters was used to calibrate the model and divide sewer flows by community.
title: Senior Project Engineer

name: Mansfield Road Storm Sewer Improvements
description: Completed H&H report for the enclosure of a stream along Mansfield Road and the effect on neighboring properties and stream conditions.
title: Senior Project Engineer

name: McKeesport, Dravosburg, Duquesne Combined Sewer Systems Hydraulic Modeling
description: H&H modeling of the McKeesport, Dravosburg, Duquesne Combined sewer systems utilizing flow monitor data and provided GIS database. Model was developed in InfoWorks ICM. Worked on but did not complete project due to change in job.
title: Senior Project Engineer

name: System Mapping Updates
description: Update of System sewer and water mapping. Migration to ArcGIS Online.
title: Senior Project Engineer

name: System Mapping and GPS Collection Program
description: Migrated GIS data form GeoPlan to ArcGIS Online. Development of a GPS collection program using ArcGIS Online Dashboards, and the Collector app to enable centimeter accuracy data collection of system manholes.
title: Senior Project Engineer

name: Vita Dump Site
description: H&H study of waste disposal site to determine H&H effect on streams and neighboring properties.
title: Senior Project Engineer

name: Water System Master Plan
client: Municipal Authority of the Township of Richland
description: I updated an existing WaterCAD model to a GIS-based InfoWater model for the Municipal Authority of the Township of Richland. This included incorporating new development within the system and location and elevation updates using GIS tools and data. Calibration involved conducting hydrant flow testing to establish pressure calibration points and pipe roughness values. Additionally, fire flows were calculated throughout the system to identify areas for future projects.
title: Senior Project Engineer

name: Zoning Map
description: Creation of zoning map using old paper maps. Migration to ArcGIS Online for publishing of public facing zoning application. Also created a Survey123 Zoning Violation tool for the Township to replace existing paper processes.
title: Senior Project Engineer

name: Zoning Map Updates
description: Creation of a Zoning map using a decades old paper map and updating by review or ordinances.
title: Senior Project Engineer

name: Admin and Personnel Building Stormwater Design And Permitting
description: Performed full stormwater management design and permitting for a new Admin & Personnel Building, including H&H analysis, two bioretention basins, and a tributary swale; prepared calculations/documentation to satisfy NPDES peak rate and volume control; coordinated with site architect and engineers to integrate stormwater infrastructure with building plans Working with the building design team, I completed H&H calculations and design of two bioretention areas and tributary swale to treat stormwater runoff and meet pear rate and volume requirement for the NPDES permit which I completed.
title: Senior Project Engineer

name: CSO Regulator No. 1 Evaluation and Replacement Concept Design
description: Completed H&H modeling and evaluation following failure of CSO Regulator No. 1; built a detailed SWMM model of the interconnected sewer/regulator system; prepared a preliminary replacement regulator/outfall concept including proposed elevations, weir sizing, and hydraulic checks After a failure of a CSO structure, an H&H study was completed to evaluate options for a permanent design of a new regulator and outfall structure. This model had multiple interconnected systems and regulators that had to be modeled.
title: Senior Project Engineer

name: Corrective Action Plan Engineering Evaluation
description: Calibrated H&H Model consisting of 5 flow monitors, pump station, forcemain, and interceptor to assist in the development of a Corrective Action Plan
title: Senior Project Engineer

name: Glannons Pump Station
description: Assisted the design team by creating a calibrated H&H model to determine design flows for a new pump station
title: Senior Project Engineer

name: Peebles Road Pump Station
description: Assisted the design team by creating a calibrated H&H model to determine design flows for a new pump station
title: Senior Project Engineer

name: Post-Construction Sewer System Model
client: Kiski Valley Water Pollution Control Authority
description: To come into compliance with PA DEP, KVWPCA communities completed sewer separation projects and plant upgrades. To establish new rates and determine flow values, I completed a Post Construction H&H model using 6 months of flow data from 75 flow meters. The model was modified and calibrated to best model the current flow conditions which were used to establish new rates. Developed and calibrated a post-construction SWMM model used to assess compliance and establish user rates; implemented model updates and calibrated hydrology/hydraulics using ~6 months of data from 75 flow monitors; compiled results and managed post-processing, QA/QC, and flow-monitor data management
title: Senior Project Engineer

name: System Map
description: Creation of System Map utilizing As-Built drawings. Migration to ArcGIS Online platform
title: Senior Project Engineer

name: System Mapping and Collection Program
client: Municipal Authority of the Township of Richland
description: Update of System map. Worked with Precision Laser to setup a collection program using Terraflex and an R2 unit. Eventual transition to Collector app and ArcGIS Online.
title: Senior Project Engineer

name: System Masterplan
description: Built system map for WEWJA using hundreds of As-built drawings. Combined data into an online webmap for use by the Authority from any device. Assisted in selection and purchase of GNSS equipment and setup and trained staff for field data collection.
title: Senior Project Engineer

name: Hydraulic Model Development
description: Leveraging existing GIS and as-built data, a water model was constructed and calibrated for the Findlay Township Municipal Authority. The InfoWater Pro model included 2 tanks, 2 booster stations, and several interconnections. Hydrant flow testing was conducted to acquire pressure calibration points and pipe roughness values. The calibrated model was used for planning system expansion, supporting bottling operations, facilitating significant commercial development, and conducting fire flow simulations and alternatives analysis for new tanks and booster pumps.
title: Senior Project Engineer

name: Water System Mapbooks
description: Updated GIS database using As-builts and constructed truck maps.
title: Senior Project Engineer

name: ALCOSAN GROW Grants (Rounds 1&3) & GI and Sewer Separation Concepts
category: Hydrologic & Hydraulic Modeling, Grant Application, GIS
description: Secured over $1.2M in ALCOSAN GROW grant funding for green infrastructure and sewer separation projects; provided preliminary stormwater designs including major separation concepts (Broadway Ave, Cubbage Ave); managed grant applications, reimbursement documentation, and supporting hydraulic analysis to meet ALCOSAN requirements For the second round of ALCOSAN GROW grants, I successfully submitted reimbursement and new separation projects for over $1 million. Successfully submitted GROW grant applications for green source reduction projects for Carnegie Borough totaling nearly $200,000.
title: Senior Project Engineer

name: CSO Program Phase 1 Design
client: Authority of the Borough of Charleroi
category: Erosion & Sedimentation Control, Permitting, Stormwater Design
description: I completed E&S and PCSM design and permitting for two pump stations and accompanying forcemains as part of the Phase 1 CSO program for ABC.
title: Senior Project Engineer

name: Camp Meeting Road Pump Station Site Design and Permitting
category: Erosion & Sedimentation Control, Permitting, Stormwater Design
description: Led stormwater site plan design and permitting for a new sanitary sewer pump station; developed E&S and PCSM plans addressing grading, drainage, and regulatory compliance; coordinated submissions and approvals with regulatory agencies Worked on E&S and PCSM design and permitting for a new pump station and sewer system for FTMA.
title: Senior Project Engineer

name: MS4 Programs
description: I completed new MS4 permits for several clients including development of MS4 mapping and Pollution Reduction Plans and helped to establish MS4 programs.
title: Senior Project Engineer

name: Wilshire Drive Culvert Replacement
category: Erosion & Sedimentation Control, Permitting, Stormwater Design
description: I completed design and permitting for a small culvert replacement for NHTMA.
title: Project Consultant

name: CEC Go Development
description: Working with a small team, I helped to develop the technical aspects of a new initiative to provide clients with new tools to evaluate sites and concepts. Using available applications, we streamlined providing online GIS maps, evaluated 3D modeling and presentation tools, and conceptualized project Dashboards that will provide one-point access to clients.
title: Project Consultant

name: Forbes Avenue Apartments
description: Coordinating Utilities and Permitting such as Tap-In and Tap-Termination plans.
title: Project Consultant

name: Power Plant Siting Certificate
client: ESC Brooke County Power I, LLC
description: As a team member on a project to prepare a sitting certificate for a new power plant I aggregated GIS data and prepared numerous exhibits to show surrounding impact, helped construct a 3D model of the plant and analyzed viewshed impacts and helped prepare various other exhibits.
title: Project Consultant

name: Company Intranet
description: KLH Engineers had been exploring the idea of an intranet to facilitate some basic business information and practices. After many meetings discussing Enterprise options, I build a simple yet functional intranet using a Google Site. Employees could see a company calendar, open new Order Entries, find project numbers, contact info, and client information, and use other tools like GIS maps and a company directory to be productive.
title: Project Engineer

name: Emerald on Centre
description: Coordinating Utilities, Permitting such as Tap-In and Tap-Termination plans, Sewage Facilities Planning Module, and Department of Public Works approval drawings.
title: Project Consultant

name: GIS Hydrology Intersection Tool
description: Automated the process of determining hydrologic routing landcover areas. The tool is written in Python and can be used within ArcGIS to intersect several layers and produce a table of areas that can be used in hydrologic calculations. This tool can turn several hours or days of work into just a few minutes and it keeps calculations organized and repeatable for frequently changing designs
title: Project Consultant

name: Greenville Stormwater GIS
description: Greenville Sanitary Authority wanted a complete catalog of their storm sewer infrastructure. To help deliver this, I generated mapbooks for their municipality that our survey crews used to GPS all catch basins, manholes and sewers. After the survey was complete, I assembled the data into a database that could be used by the Authority to track the status of their infrastructure, such as which catch basins needed to be cleaned. The deliverable was a set of detailed maps showing all relevant elevations and sizes of their storm infrastructure.
title: Project Engineer

name: Oakland Avenue Commercial Development
category: Land Development, Grading, Erosion & Sedimentation Control, Permitting, Stormwater Design
description: As part of land development for Indy-Apple, LLC , I worked with project managers and other team members to layout a site plan for two restaurants and a hotel along Oakland Avenue. I assisted in drafting a land development package, running stormwater calculations, submitting various permitting packages including NPDES and I coordinated with utility companies and other permitting entities.
title: Project Engineer

name: Order Entry System
description: The existing Order Entry system for starting new projects consisted of paper forms being filled out by hand and delivered to various personnel by hand or via email with multiple copies. To organize this process I utilized Google Forms and JavaScript to build an online Order Entry system. New jobs could be opened, assigned project numbers and engineers from any device with an internet connection. Emails and PDFs were automatically generated and a master tracking spreadsheet was appended so that all open projects could be reviewed in monthly meetings.
title: Project Engineer

name: The Bible Chapel
category: Land Development, Grading, Erosion & Sedimentation Control, Permitting
description: As part of The Bible Chapel 's new worship center project, I assisted in site layout and preliminary grading of the site. I also helped prepare the Land Development submission, coordinated with utility companies, drafted the Highway Occupancy Permits and Sewage Facilities Planning Module.
title: Project Consultant

name: The Empire
description: This project for the Park7 Group consisted of civil site work for a new 17-story apartment building. I worked with utility companies, the architect and general contractor to determine site utility connections and prepared a stormwater design to capture runoff. I also helped to prepare various permit submissions and communicated weekly with the design team.
title: Project Consultant

name: Aleppo Sewer Map
description: I scanned old paper maps and georeferenced them to State Plane coordinates along with old CAD files. I then created a GIS map with all the legacy information for use by the Authority to manage their assets.
title: Project Engineer

name: Allegheny Valley GIS and Flow Monitoring Plan
description: Allegheny Valley Joint Sewage Authority needed to quantify flows in its system as well as flows entering from neighboring communities. Using GIS I planned for surveys to be conducted of the system and then processed this survey data into a detail GIS for use in planning flow monitoring locations. Coordination with officials in neighboring communities was required to ensure all connections were accounted for.
title: Project Engineer

name: Carnegie Flooding Hydraulic Investigation
description: Carnegie suffered a significant flood after a >100 year storm that caused damage to streets and basements below Carnegie Park. Engineers worked to plan additional sewers system improvements to alleviate the flooding for 100 year storms. I coordinated flow monitoring at a key choke point and used the data to develop a H&H model of the watershed and conveyance system. This aided in sizing additional sewers and determining alternative alignments and elevations of parallel sewers.
title: Project Engineer

name: Carnegie Overflow Regression Model
description: As part of a NPDES permit, Carnegie is required to complete a Discharge Monitoring Reports (DMR) to report overflows from an outfall in their system. Instead of installing a permanent flow meter, we installed a temporary flow meter and a rainmeter for several months of data collection. Using this data I built a multiple linear regression model to predict overflow volumes based on rainfall from public rain stations. The model was implemented into an Excel spreadsheet to allow rainfall data to be easily enters and predicted volumes calculated.
title: Project Engineer

name: Clairton Billing Meters
description: New billing meters needed to be constructed along two main interceptors that collect sewage from neighboring municipalities. I helped to draft new vaults to contain Palmer-Bowlus flumes and determined the hydraulic parameters that needed to be met. I also helped to collect survey information for an existing vault located in a remote area.
title: Project Engineer

name: Duquesne and Dravosburg Hydraulic Models
description: The City of McKeesport Municipal Authority acquired the treatment systems for Duquesne and Dravosburg. In order to complete a Long Term Control Plan for each system and an Act 537 report, KLH had to show that the system was capable of conveying all flows to treatment including 350% of peak dry flow. In addition, a H&H model was needed to evaluate future plans for the two systems. Without high quality data, I coordinated a survey of the existing conveyance systems including field work to verify specific details. Using this data I build a GIS and used it to build an H&H model for each system. I then evaluated each system to determine compliance with the requirements.
title: Project Engineer

name: Elizabeth Watershed Drainage Maps
description: Although large watersheds that are more than a few acres are readily available. Small watersheds need delineated by hand. Using geoprocessing available in MapWindow, I authored dozens of exhibits showing small watersheds as calculated by software. These watersheds are produced in a few minutes and are almost always as accurate as hand delineated ones.
title: Project Engineer

name: Water System Consolidation Plan
description: Following the acquisition of Millcreek Township Water Authority, I oversaw the completion of an update and expansion of the InfoWater model. This involved adding 9 pump stations and 5 water tanks across several new pressure districts. The new model was calibrated, and model results were provided in support of a revised Master Plan.
title: Project Engineer

name: Frey Pump Station Model
description: The Moon Township Municipal Authority was experiencing flooding near one of its pump stations where the flows were not being conveyed to the pump station. I coordinated flow monitoring around the pump station and created an H&H model to identify the problem areas in the system and make recommendations in order to convey storm flows to the pump station without overflows. Performed on-site flow monitoring siting to address pump station flooding in a complex sewer system; sited six monitors, iterated locations as data arrived, and provided QA/QC to support pump station upgrade analysis; supported SWMM modeling to evaluate flood-alleviation alternatives
title: Project Engineer

name: GIS Mapbook Reproduction
description: Shaler Municipal Authority was in possession of paper mapbooks of their sewer collection system that were used by their office and by field crews. Although they also had some of the GIS used to create these paper mapbooks, they were not able to print more when needed. To assist them, I obtained a page of their mapbook and built a one-to-one recreation that included some requested modifications including color coded pipe sizes. The deliverable was several sets of bound and laminated map books that their field crews could use to identify locations and connectivity of their system.
title: Project Engineer

name: Mt. Lebanon Painter's Run Hydraulic Models
description: Gateway Engineers proposed a new sewer alignment and profile in Mt. Lebanon to decrease flooding issues. There was concern that increasing capacity of upstream segments would lead to flooding issues along main arteries further down the conveyance system. I processed flow data and integrated it into H&H models to show how the hydraulic profile and capacity of the system changed with several different modifications to the alignment. A report made recommendations concerning the proposed construction.
title: Project Engineer

name: Peters DC Sewer Interceptor Model Validation
description: The Authority's previous engineer had completed an H&H model of the two main interceptors tributary to one of the wastewater treatment plants. After additional survey data collection, I corrected errors in the model and modeled possible scenarios for system augmentation including upsizing of sewers and bolting of manholes to prevent blowouts.
title: Project Engineer

name: Stoops Ferry Model
description: The Moon Township Municipal Authority requested assistance to quantify flooding and overflows at a pump station, capacity issues and sizing and locating potential equalization basins. Using the Authority's existing GIS information and scanned drawings, I constructed a H&H model and calibrated to existing flow data that needed to be processed. The deliverable was a presentation showing the calibration of the model and identification of potential causes of flooding along with recommendations for upsizing and relining of pipes and potential equalization basin locations.
title: Project Engineer

name: Youghiogheny WWTP Process Lift Station Model
description: NHTMA was preparing to upgrade several pump stations and wanted to study the process lift station at the WWTP to determine if upsizing was needed to prevent flooding that was occurring in one of their main interceptors. Using previous flow monitoring data, I constructed an InfoSWMM model and calibrated it to be able to predict flows for large storms and future growth. This included modeling multiple pump stations and a large basin. I was able to recommend locations for additional flow monitoring to increase the usefulness of the model.
title: Project Engineer

name: Act 537 Maps using Python
description: As a requirement of PA Act 537, several exhibits needed to be created regularly for submission to the PA DEP. These exhibits included data such as soil information and floodplain locations. In order to reduce the tediousness of assembling these exhibits, I programmed a Python script to run inside of ArcGIS to automate the process. To accomplish this, I created statewide datasets of relevant data. The process was reduced from a weeks worth of work for one submission to just a few minutes. The user needed to simply draw an area of interest and fill in some information and in one click, the required PDFs were generated.
title: Project Engineer

name: Aleppo System Map Update
description: I used a combination of paper maps, shapefiles and CAD drawings to create a GIS of the water distribution system for Aleppo to facilitate their asset management.
title: Project Engineer

name: Clairton GIS - CCTV Integration
description: The Clairton Municipal Authority contracted with a pipe televising company to produce a city-wide database of pipe inspections of their combined sewer system. The deliverable was a hard drive containing hundreds of gigabytes of photos and video for each pipe in the system. Additionally, the inspections were conducted without a clear agreement of maps to be used to identify structures and pipes. As a result the Authority had a huge amount of disorganized data that was difficult to access and extract actionable information from. To solve this, I obtained various paper and digital maps that were available and processed them into one GIS with clear and logical naming conventions. I then utilized commercial software to create geolocated features for each pipe defect that was recorded by the contractor. I then linked the CCTV photos and video to the actual inspection locations. The deliverable product was a free-to-use GIS map that the Authority could use to identify exactly where problems were located in their collection system and then view the inspection video without using additional software.
title: Project Engineer

name: Creswell Web GIS Proposal
description: The Authority was interested in better managing their water distribution infrastructure. They currently had to pull paper cards for each meter and valve to be serviced. I took an old water model and some CAD drawings and created a GIS using georeferencing. I then created an interactive online version that would allow anyone to pull up information on any valve, hydrant or meter based on location. We proposed further refining the GIS using GPS and data entry from their paper system.
title: Project Engineer

name: Flow Data Processing Script
category: Coding, Tool Development, Hydrologic & Hydraulic Modeling
description: Flow data is used for the calibration and validation of hydraulic models. This data requires processing to ensure uniformity and to prepare for use in several modeling applications such as SWMM and SSOAP. I wrote Excel VBA code to convert data between 5-,15-, and 60-minute data using averages and then format into various rain depth, flow, head, and velocity time series and to export csv files.
title: Project Engineer

name: Hampton Headworks Model
description: Modeled a short system of sewer entering a WWTP in order to help size the headworks and determine any system issues.
title: Project Engineer

name: Larimer Model
description: NHTMA needed to model a gravity portion of their system using existing flow data in order to determine what lines needed upsized before the downstream WWTP upgrades were to be completed so that the connection to the wetwell and the capacity of the system was coordinated.
title: Project Engineer

name: Robinson Run Model
description: Helped the South Fayette Municipal Authority to troubleshoot an existing H&H model and determine RTK parameters for their catchment areas which entered a multi municipal interceptor. This helped to keep their share of the maintenance and upgrade costs of the shared system in line with what flow they were actually producing.
title: Project Engineer

name: Environmental Fluid Mechanics Laboratory
description: Planned and coordinated a new Environmental Fluid Mechanics Laboratory that included four large flumes and several small exhibits. I worked with several other members of the research group to rehabilitate an old flume that was previously in storage. We also worked on building an intermediate sized flume and planned and constructed a small flume including channel design, plumbing, pump selection,electrical coordination, and a sediment collection system.
title: Research Assistant

name: Tipon Channel Physical Model
description: The Tipon channels in Peru demonstrate an understanding of hydraulic principles by the Inca civilization. Irrigation channels were built to convey water down steep gradients without allowing flows to transition from supercritical to subcritical flow. When that transition occurs, hydraulic jumps can be found. Understanding and managing this transition can reduce hydraulic jumps and reduce damage to your channel. As part of a group, I helped to build a computer model of a channel that achieved the same effect and then I planned and built a flume that let us compare the effect of energy dissipation from different surface roughnesses.
title: Graduate Student

name: Tree Roots and Shear Stress Investigation
category: Research, Field Work, Hydrologic & Hydraulic Modeling
description: Stream channel development in forested areas is profoundly influenced by large organic debris with enters the stream after erosion during high flow events. While it is well documented that increased density of roots in stream banks can increase the strength of the bank, the hydraulic process that arise from rootwads along stream banks is less well understood. This project sought to better understand the effect on shear stress that complicated flow cross sections present. To study this, LIDAR scanning of streambanks and modeling of flows around rootwads was conducted.
title: Graduate Student

name: Civil Department Webmaster
description: Worked with faculty to maintain the entire Civil & Environmental Engineering webpage including keeping forms up to date, adding new web pages and helping professors update their personal pages.
title: Undergraduate Student

name: Pool-Riffle Shear Stress Models
description: Pool-Riffle stream structures can be found in nature and can demonstrate self-maintaining qualities by alternating high and low flows and then reversing flow regimes during high flow events. Modeling of these structures is typically done using one-dimensional models such as HEC-RAS. However, the reversal mechanism may not be found when a two-dimensional model is used. I compared a HEC-RAS and River2D model for several geometries and flow regimes to demonstrate the need to model these structures using more complex models. This paper was recognized at the 2011 World Environmental & Water Resources Congress for coming in 1st place for the student competition.
title: Undergraduate Student

name: Allegheny National Forest Gas Survey
description: NETL was to deploy a new mobile air quality monitoring trailer. Testing of this trailer was proposed to be in the Allegheny National Forest which is dense with oil and gas wells. Utilizing a Leak Detection System, the team planned an efficient route to drive throughout and around the forest to detect methane and hydrocarbons from leaking wells. We identified several areas with significant levels of methane detected and presented our findings to staff.
title: Intern

name: Duquesne and Dravosburg Hydraulic Models & Long Term Control Plan
description: The City of McKeesport Municipal Authority acquired the treatment systems for Duquesne and Dravosburg. In order to complete a Long Term Control Plan for each system and an Act 537 report, KLH had to show that the system was capable of conveying all flows to treatment including 350% of peak dry flow. In addition, an H&H model was needed to evaluate future plans for the two systems. Without high quality data, I coordinated a survey of the existing conveyance systems including field work to verify specific details. Using this data I built a GIS and used it to build an H&H model for each system. I then evaluated each system to determine compliance with the requirements. Led flow monitoring and SWMM modeling for LTCP capacity/alternatives analysis; selected 12 flow monitor locations using mapping and field investigation of regulator structures; managed data collection/quality and calibrated to the minimum effective monitoring span to control costs.
title: Project Engineer

name: GIS Development and Implementation
description: Supported GIS team in the transformation of GPS survey data, resolved quality issues, and ensured accurate GNSS receiver integration with ArcGIS Field Maps and a well-organized schema; performed QA/QC on field-collected data and supported web map projection setup for reliable workflows

name: GIS Countywide DEM Processing Support
description: Working with existing GIS team on this project, evaluated and troubleshot watershed-scale processing scripts (including migration to an alternate platform for testing and reliability); executed/monitored large watershed runs, resolved failures, and produced county-scale watershed delineations and statistics using Python raster/vector workflows; merged results and delivered processed datasets for analysis
title: Professional Engineer

name: GIS System Migration and Integration

name: Interceptor H&H Modeling and Calibration

title: Senior Project Engineer
